newsitem.title: UK: Major to call on teenagers to join cadets - paper.
newsitem.headline: Major to call on teenagers to join cadets - paper.

text.p: Prime Minister John Major has backed plans for every British schoolchild to be given the chance to become a military cadet under plans to encourage self-disciplince, loyalty and fitness, the Times newspaper said.

Millions of pounds would be spent on setting up new centres in schools and inner-city areas, equipping them and recruiting former service personnel to train the cadets, the paper said in its Thursday edition.

The plan to extend Britain's 130,000-strong cadet force, which could be announced next month, is being backed by Major, Defence Secretary Michael Portillo and Education Secretary Gillian Shephard, the Times said.

An announcement in the run-up to the next election would enable the ruling Conservative Party to espouse a policy that would clearly differentiate it from the opposition Labour Party, which has become increasingly centrist in other areas.
Major, whose party is trailing Labour by about 17 points in opinion polls, must call an election by May.
According to their biographers, neither Major nor Portillo took the opportunity to join the cadets when they were at school.
Cadet forces, designed to instil military virtues in teenagers, exist at 198 private schools but at only 45 state schools.
Portillo was quoted as saying: "The cadets are a good thing because they help young people to develop self-discipline, self-motivation and qualities of leadership.

"They make young people team players, give them self-esteem and satisfy their love of adventure. For some young people they point the way to a career in the military, for others they simply lead to more knowledge about themselves."
